newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP faces probe for insider trading.
newsitem.headline: SAP faces probe for insider trading.

text.p: Frankfurt prosecutors said on Monday they were investigating possible insider trading in shares of software maker SAP AG in one of the most serious cases seen in Germany to date.
"The investigation is looking at the use of insider knowledge in the trading of shares," prosecutor spokesman Job Tilmann told Reuters.
Tillmann declined to identify individuals targeted in the probe. "At the moment we are not naming specific people," he said. "The investigation is just beginning. It is too early."
Business daily Handelsblatt on Monday reported the probe was looking at trades by more than 100 persons, including members of SAP's supervisory and management boards.
The newspaper quoted SAP spokesman Michael Pfister as saying, "We are aware of the investigations."
Pfister said the investigations were routine, in connection with sharp price movements in the company's shares. All necessary records haD been handed over to the oversight authority, Pfister said.
SAP was not immediately available for comment on Monday.
The investigation covered trading by employees, their relatives and friends immediately prior to a company announcement on October 23, 1996, Tilmann said.
Within minutes of the announcement -- that nine-month profit was below expectations -- SAP shares fell 23.6 percent to 212 marks on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange.
Tilmann said the initial investigation could be finished in about a month.
Telephone records are being examined as evidence in the case, Handelsblatt said.
Germany's Federal Authority for Securities Trading notified prosecutors of suspicions of insider trading in January, Tilmann said.
Handelsblatt quoted authority spokesman Juergen Oberfrank as saying the case was one of the largest and most serious since a new German insider trading law took effect in 1994.
